title: Ghost of ETA refuses to fade for Spanish right
text:
ALSASUA, Spain — ETA ended its terrorist campaign for an independent Basque Country eight years ago. But the separatist group’s legacy continues to play a prominent role in Spain’s polarized politics, with politicians on the right claiming its influence is still alive and well in the north of the country.

Over the last three years, the small town of Alsasua has been the backdrop to a deeply controversial judicial case that epitomizes the fraught relationship between Spain’s conservative unionists and its nationalist periphery.

Nestled in the mountains an hour’s drive from the French border, Alsasua is in the region of Navarre, which borders the Basque region and is claimed as part of the Basque homeland by nationalists.

“We are being used as puppets in a game,” said Edurne Goikoetxea, a local woman. “A narrative is being peddled about Alsasua and the whole of Navarre and the Basque Country as a place of conflict.”

Goikoetxea is the mother of Ainara Urquijo, one of eight young people from the town who were given jail sentences last year for their role in a late-night incident in a bar in October 2016 in which two plain-clothes civil guards were injured. One of them broke his ankle and two women who were accompanying the civil guards were also hurt.

ETA declared a definitive ceasefire in 2011, ending a four-decade campaign of violence in which it killed more than 800 people.

Those jailed insist that what happened that night was simply a drunken scuffle. But prosecutors disagreed, claiming that the clash had been part of a concerted strategy of hostility by a faction of local people who aimed to drive security forces from the town.

Prosecutor José Perals described their actions as part of “a legacy of terror in the Basque Country and Navarre which is a continuation of the terrorism that Spain has lived through for 50 years.”

He brought terrorism charges against the defendants, calling for jail sentences of up to 62 years. The Madrid court that tried them eventually dropped the terror-related charges. However, ruling that the assault had been driven by “radicalization, animosity and intolerance” toward the security forces, it gave seven of them jail sentences ranging from nine to 13 years for assault and public disorder. Urquijo received a two-year jail sentence for threatening behavior and has been released.

“This whole situation has been a farce from the beginning,” said Haizea Ramirez de Alda, whose brother Adur received a 12-year sentence. She, like Goikoetxea, believes the civil guard, judiciary and politicians have colluded to manipulate this case in an effort to fabricate a common enemy in northern Spain.

Parties on the political right say that the Alsasua incident, like the homecoming ceremonies, shows how ETA’s influence still lingers.

“Some of the powers don’t want to accept that we are in a new period of peace in the Basque Country because they are not comfortable without ETA,” she said.

The defendants in the case — seven of them have been in preventive custody for nearly three years — are now waiting for the Supreme Court to rule on their appeal against the sentences.

Lingering influence

ETA declared a definitive ceasefire in 2011, ending a four-decade campaign of violence in which it killed more than 800 people. In May of 2018, it formally disbanded.

But many Spaniards believe it has left open wounds. Terrorism victims’ groups say over 300 ETA killings have not been resolved. They also denounce so-called ongi etorri — jubilant ceremonies for ETA members on their release from prison. In one recent example, Basque flags were brandished and fireworks let off in tribute to José Javier Zabaleta, a former ETA commander who had spent 29 years in jail, when he returned to his hometown of Hernani.

Parties on the political right say that the Alsasua incident, like the homecoming ceremonies, shows how ETA’s influence still lingers.

“There is a part of Alsasua society that is sick and which spreads hatred against everything that Spain represents,” said Javier Esparza, president of the Navarrese People’s Union (UPN), a right-of-center regional party.

Speaking at the UPN headquarters in Navarre’s capital Pamplona, Esparza said his party is unable to put up local candidates in towns like Alsasua, despite having voters there, because they fear harassment from Basque nationalists.

He describes EH Bildu, the pro-independence political party that is seen to represent many of the voters who once supported ETA and has seats in Alsasua and many other town halls, as a front for the terrorist group.

“Before, they used to murder civil guards, now they beat them up,” he said.

Gorka Landaburu, editor of the current affairs publication Cambio 16, believes such appraisals of the Alsasua episode are exaggerated.

Locals frequently complain of harassment by the civil guard — who are posted to Navarre from other parts of Spain.

“It was a serious incident, but this was a disproportionate sentence for what was a bar brawl,” he said.

Landaburu, who survived an attempt on his life by ETA in 2001, also sees the furor surrounding Alsasua bleeding into national politics.

“The hardcore right is using Alsasua for electoral reasons,” he said.

In the fall of 2018, the leader of the stridently unionist Ciudadanos party, Albert Rivera, staged an event in the town as a show of support for the two civil guards involved in the bar incident. With representatives of the conservative Popular Party (PP) and the far-right Vox also attending, the visit was seen as highly provocative.

Then, in March of this year, PP leader Pablo Casado riled many Alsasua locals when he gave an interview to right-wing journalist Eduardo Inda in the Koxka bar where the civil guards were injured.

'Occupation force'

According to Spain’s right, such gestures demonstrate unionist resolve and contrast with the left’s tolerance of radical Basque nationalism. For proof, they point to the Socialist María Chivite, who became president of the Navarre region in August, her successful investiture being made possible by the abstention of EH Bildu. Although the Socialist Party denies having made any concessions to EH Bildu, the opposition is not convinced.

Ciudadanos has described the supposed agreement behind the abstention as “the mother of all infamies.” Esparza, meanwhile, claimed that Chivite had made a deal with “ETA’s front men.”

Socialist acting Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez has faced similar charges. A parliamentary no-confidence motion that made him prime minister in 2018 flourished partly because EH Bildu backed it, a fact Rivera, Casado and others have not let him forget. As he seeks to form a new government in the coming weeks, the Basque nationalists’ cooperation might once again play a role.

Yet Socialists did briefly find common ground with the right recently in the Navarre parliament when they voted together to condemn an annual event in Alsasua known in the Basque language as Ospa Eguna (“Farewell day”), which calls for the expulsion of Spanish security forces from the town. It is a mainly festive occasion, with a cross-country run, a town square banquet and street demonstrations, albeit with a very serious message: that the civil guard, which has barracks nearby, is not welcome.

Locals frequently complain of harassment by the civil guard — who are posted to Navarre from other parts of Spain — and the regional police. Many describe their presence as an “occupation.”

Ospa Eguna “is the day when we make clear we don’t want [Spanish] security forces in our country,” said Aitor, a young man who preferred not to give his surname. “We suffer police repression on a day-to-day basis — they stop us, they ask for documents, they threaten us, because they see that we don’t want to be part of their state.”

But while this poor relationship with the police was for a long time the major factor behind widespread mistrust of the Spanish state in nationalist towns like Alsasua, the ongoing court case now seems to have convinced many people that the judiciary and political class are also against them.

Landaburu says such issues make it difficult to give peace a chance.

“It’s a great shame for the majority of people in Alsasua and in Navarre and the Basque Country,” he said. “They want peaceful coexistence.”
description: Although separatist group ended its terrorist campaign eight years ago,  its legacy plays a prominent role in Spain’s politics.
